Comment                                 Intracerebral injection of A-beta-containing brain extracts caused cerebral beta-amyloidosis (refs. 1 and 2), with a dependence on host and source proteins that suggested the existence of A-beta prion strains| Low-n oligomers isolated from human Alzheimer's disease brains contained pyroglutamated A-beta that triggered neuronal damage and loss in lab mice at 3 months,
in a tau-dependent manner (ref. 3) | Intracerebral inoculation of preparations of purely synthetic A-beta amyloid and of A-beta amyloid purified from human Alzheimer's brains caused A-beta amyloidosis in mice [ref. 4]. However, these mice can spontaneously acquire amyloidosis without such inoculations |Intracerebral injection of A-beta brain extracts into a transgenic rat model that does not otherwise develop A-beta deposition, causes A-beta amyloidosis [ref. 5]. These results indicate that A-beta might be a prion protein; however, the amyloid inoculations are derived from brain extracts, and not generated in vitro, so it is unclear whether additional co-factors in the brain extracts are necessary|Interacts with PD0015 , determined by: surface plasmon resonance|

Comment                                 The propagating aggregated form is a synthetic engineered construct of the WH1 domain of RepA with an amyloid-promoting (A31V) mutation [1,2]| The aggregated form is propagated progressively in E coli progeny cells. This amyloidopathy causes reduced fitness, through longer generation times| Thus, RepA-WH1 could be a synthetic engineered prion, since it is made from an E coli protein expressed in E coli that can propagate to progeny, as a disease that reduces fitness|This entry is not classified as 'transcellular prionoid', because E.coli is not a multicellular organism.  Also, it is not clear whether non-mutant full-length RepA is amyloidogenic in E. coli cells (either functionally or as a 'disease')|

|
Wang IF, Chang HY, Hou SC, Liou GG, Way TD, James Shen CK. _The self-interaction of native TDP-43 C terminus inhibits its degradation and contributes to early proteinopathies. _Nat Commun. 2012 Apr 3;3:766. _    22473010

Comment                                 TDP-43 cytoplasmic aggregates are implicated in ALS. TDP-43 contains a domain with yeast prion-like composition, whose aggregation has been re-capitulated in a budding yeast model     proteinopathy, and which profoundly affects yeast colony growth [1,2]. These aggregates are not amyloid-like. The TDP-43 C-terminus physically interacts with itself or with the Sup35 prion domain to form aggregates. This quasi-prion behaviour modulates known cellular functions of TDP-43 [3]
|

PrionHome Id                            PD2534
Uniprot                                 Q7Z434
SwissProt                               MAVS_HUMAN
Source Organism                         Homo sapiens (Human)
Taxonomy                                Eukaryota › Metazoa › Chordata › Craniata › Vertebrata › Euteleostomi › Mammalia › Eutheria › Euarchontoglires › Primates › Haplorrhini › Catarrhini › Hominidae › Homo
Sequence Length                         540
Protein Name                            Mitochondrial Antiviral-Signaling Protein (MAVS)
Prion Name                              N/A
Sequence                                
PrionHome Classification                Quasi-Prion
Evidence For PrionHome Classification   Experimental propagation within cells, and infection with MAVS aggregates that were formed in vitro
Prion Determinant
Compositionally Biased Regions          103/455/1.319934e-25/PSAGT;180/446/1.608542e-10/S;519/533/1.273285e-05/V;262/291/1.137809e-04/A;396/492/2.471399e-04/G;191/398/3.056581e-04/T
Known Disordered Regions
Predicted Disordered Regions            1/6;94/126;132/226;229/247;251/294;320/344;375/422;452/452;454/460;480/508;541/568
Reference                               Hou F, Sun L, Zheng H, Skaug B, Jiang QX, Chen ZJ. _MAVS forms functional
prion-like aggregates to activate and propagate antiviral innate immune response. _Cell. 2011 Aug 5;146(3):448-61. Epub 2011 Jul 21. _21782231
|
Ye J, Maniatis T. _A prion-like trigger of antiviral signaling. _Cell. 2011 Aug
5;146(3):348-50. _21816270

Comment                                 The functional form of MAVS is an amyloid-like aggregate that can co-opt other copies of the protein into the aggregated form. The aggregates are made from residues 1-218 of MAVS, which includes a CARD domain. This form plays a role in the assembly of anti-viral signaling complexes on the mitochondrial membrane [1,2].
This mode of formation is similar to the functional intra-cellular assembly of CPEB (PD2090). MAVS aggregates that are formed in vitro can be introduced into cells to propagate the aggregated form to other copies of the MAVS protein, in the absence of viral infection. However, since these cells are cell lines derived from a metazoan organism, we do not classify MAVS as a prion (if it was it would be an Am* prion).  |

Fragment

Structure Information

Reference                               Gilks N, Kedersha N, Ayodele M, Shen L, Stoecklin G, Dember LM, Anderson P. _Stress granule assembly is mediated by prion-like aggregation of TIA-1. _ Mol Biol Cell. 2004 Dec;15(12):5383-98. Epub 2004 Sep 15. _15371533
Comment                                  TIA-1 is an RNA binding protein that functions in stress granule (SG) assembly| SGs are cytoplasmic inclusions into which stalled translation initiation complexes are dynamically
recruited during environmental stress| TIA-1 has a domain with prion-like composition, that
exhibits concentration-dependent aggregation that is regulated by molecular chaperones| The
TIA-1 prion-like domain can be functionally substituted with the Sup35-NM prion determinant
domain| Prion-like aggregation of TIA-1 regulates SG formation during environmental stress|

Reference                               Xing Y, Nakamura A, Chiba T, Kogishi K, Matsushita T, Li F, Guo Z, Hosokawa M, Mori M, Higuchi K. _Transmission of mouse senile amyloidosis_ Lab Invest. 2001 Apr;81(4):493-9._ 11304568|

Xing Y, Nakamura A, Korenaga T, Guo Z, Yao J, Fu X, Matsushita T, Kogishi K, Hosokawa M, Kametani F, Mori M, Higuchi K. _Induction of protein conformational change in mouse senile amyloidosis_ J Biol Chem. 2002 Sep 6;277(36):33164-9._ 12077115|


Fu X, Korenaga T, Fu L, Xing Y, Guo Z, Matsushita T, Hosokawa M, Naiki H, Baba S, Kawata Y, Ikeda S, Ishihara T, Mori M, Higuchi K. _Induction of AApoAII amyloidosis by various heterogeneous amyloid fibrils._ FEBS Lett. 2004 Apr 9;563(1-3):179-84._ 15063745
Comment                                 Mouse senile amyloidosis is a ubiquitous disease in laboratory mice, primarily caused by Apolipoprotein A-II amyloids (AApoAII). AApoAII amyloid caused induction of AApoAII amyloid disease in young mice through a variety of routes: peripheral injection; being imbibed in drinking water; or eating the faeces of co-habitant old mice with senile amyloidosis [ref. 1]|

Also, AApoAII amyloidosis can be induced in mouse strains that are naturally rarely susceptible, via injection of AApoAII amyloid fibrils [ref. 2]|

However, amyloidosis can also be induced non-specifically, through injection of a variety of other amyloid preparations [ref. 3], and amyloid preparations may contain other molecules that can induce amyloidosis, so definition of this as a prion phenomenon is unclear|

Reference                               Brown JC, Lindquist S._A heritable switch in carbon source utilization driven by an unusual yeast prion. _Genes Dev. 2009 Oct 1;23(19):2320-32.  _19797769
Comment                                 Prion activity: The [GAR+] prion makes cells resistant to the glucose-associated repression of alternative carbon sources. Cells can be infected with the prion through transfer of non-genetic material, e.g. in the cytoplasm during mating, or through cytoduction. |
Std1 is required for inducing the [GAR+] prion, and several lines of evidence indicate that a complex of Std1 and Pma1 is the normal activated form of the [GAR+] prion| Experiments
indicate, however, that Std1 is not required for the maintenance of
the [GAR+] prion, once it has been induced|

Comment                                 Prion activity: Sfp1 is essential for normal cell division and growth. Formation
of the [ISP+] prion does not cause loss of Sfp1 function. [ISP+] demonstrates non-Mendelian inheritance; deletion of Sfp1 causes loss of the prion, whereas overexpression causes its induction. [ISP+] nuclei contain aggregates of Sfp1 (i.e., it is a nuclear prion). [ISP+] causes
anti-suppression, the opposite of the effect of [PSI+] in yeast cells|

A novel prion strain was created in these experiments. Wang, et al. (2012) showed that PrP prions made from recombinant PrP (formed in the presence of synthetic lipids and non-genetic nucleic acids) can cause prion propagation and disease in wild-type mice|

Comment                                 Refs. 1-2 demonstrate transmission of Lewy body-like aggregates into cells, and from cell to cell| In ref.3, injections of in-vitro-derived amyloids made from recombinant protein into the brains of wild-type mice caused cell-to-cell transmission of pathologic alpha-synuclein and Parkinson's-like Lewy pathology, with subsequent symptoms of neurodegeneration in mice. These experiments thus fulfil the criteria for alpha-synuclein to be labelled a Prion Am*|

(2004) showed that PrP prions made from recombinant mouse PrP(89–230) amyloid can propagate prions into, and cause prion disease in transgenic Tg9949 mice overexpressing mouse PrP(89–230). A novel prion strain was created in these experiments. Wang, et al. (2012) showed that PrP prions made from recombinant PrP (formed in the presence of synthetic lipids and non-genetic nucleic acids) can cause prion propagation and disease in wild-type mice|

Reference                               Glover JR, Kowal AS, Schirmer EC, Patino MM, Liu JJ, Lindquist S._Self-seeded fibers formed by Sup35, the protein determinant of [PSI+], a heritable prion-like factor of S. cerevisiae. _Cell. 1997 May 30;89(5):811-9._9182769|

Sparrer HE, Santoso A, Szoka FC Jr, Weissman JS._Evidence for the prion hypothesis: induction of the yeast [PSI+] factor by in vitro- converted Sup35 protein. _Science. 2000 Jul 28;289(5479):595-9._10915616


Comment                                 Prion activity: Since Sup35p functions in translation termination, formation of [PSI+] causes increased stop-codon readthrough|
Some [PSI+] yeast strains can cause revelation of phenotypic diversity when exposed to a variety of environmental stresses/conditions, thus enhancing the evolvability of
yeast strains during periods of environmental stress|
However, other variants of [PSI+] are lethal and can be considered as diseases of yeast|

The prion hypothesis for [PSI+] has been strongly validated through propagation into yeast cells of [PSI+] prions made from recombinant Sup35p aggregates [ref. 2]|

PrionHome Id                            PD2595
Uniprot                                 P07884
SwissProt                               MOD5_YEAST
Source Organism                         Saccharomyces cerevisiae (strain ATCC 204508 / S288c) (Baker's yeast)
Taxonomy                                Eukaryota > Fungi > Dikarya > Ascomycota > Saccharomycotina > Saccharomycetes > Saccharomycetales > Saccharomycetaceae > Saccharomyces
Sequence Length                         428
Protein Name                            tRNA dimethylallyltransferase, mitochondrial
Prion Name                              [MOD+] Prion Type Am*
Sequence                                
PrionHome Classification                Prion
Evidence For PrionHome Classification
Prion Determinant                       194/217/mass spectrometry
Compositionally Biased Regions          114/424/1.580352e-06/KY;54/113/1.648585e-05/HI;83/240/4.092069e-04/Y;17/107/9.223148e-04/I;300/344/9.478387e-04/I
Known Disordered Regions
Predicted Disordered Regions            1/3;126/134;403/413;424/429
Reference                               Suzuki G, Shimazu N, Tanaka M._A yeast prion, Mod5, promotes acquired drug resistance and cell survival under
environmental stress. _ Science. 2012 Apr 20;336(6079):355-9._22517861
Comment                                 [MOD+] is heritable through cytoduction and through injection of in-vitro-made recombinant prions|[MOD+] prion aggregates sequester soluble MOD5, resulting in decreased levels of (i6A)-modified tRNAs and higher ergosterol levels, due to less competition for ERG20 (P08524), which uses the same substrate DMAPP as MOD5. [MOD+] can be cured by GdnHCl and by deletion of the molecular chaperone Hsp104 (P31539), which is required for [MOD+] propagation. The [MOD+] state acquires resistance against antifungal agents that inhibit ergosterol biosynthesis.
De novo appearance of [MOD+] is favored by the presence of antifungal agents, and the growth advantage of [MOD+] is lost when the cells are released from the selective pressure. Thus, the conformational switch of MOD5 from a soluble state to a prion state allows the cell to adapt to the harmful environment of anti-fungal drugs by up-regulating ergosterol biosynthesis at the expense of tRNA modification.|
Variant
Fragment

The UniProt sequence Q5PSB2 is a redundant protein sequence identical to this one|Ortholog of PD0015 Human Prion Protein|Legname, et al. (2004) showed that PrP prions made from recombinant mouse PrP(89–230) amyloid can propagate prions into, and cause prion disease in transgenic Tg9949 mice overexpressing mouse PrP(89–230). A novel prion strain was created in these experiments. Wang, et al. (2012) showed that PrP prions made from recombinant PrP (formed in the presence of synthetic lipids and non-genetic nucleic acids) can cause prion propagation and disease in wild-type mice|

Comment                                 Paralog of PD0032|Paralog of PD0044|Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|

Comment                                 Interacts with PD0028|Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|Alberti, et al. (2009) determined Candidate-Prion proteins using an HMM algorithm trained on the sequences of four known yeast prion determinants| Both 'core' and 'extended' prion determinants were predicted by the algorithm|

Comment                                 Interacts with PD0035|Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|Alberti, et al. (2009) determined Candidate-Prion proteins using an HMM algorithm trained on the sequences of four known yeast prion determinants| Both 'core' and 'extended' prion determinants were predicted by the algorithm|
Variant
Fragment

Epub 2007 Feb 3._17320905 |Harrison PM._Exhaustive assignment of compositional bias reveals universally prevalent biased regions: analysis of functional associations in human and Drosophila. _BMC Bioinformatics. 2006 Oct 10;7:441._17032452 |Harrison PM, Gerstein M. _A method to assess compositional bias in biological sequences and its application to prion-like glutamine/asparagine-rich domains in eukaryotic proteomes. _Genome Biol. 2003;4(6):R40. Comment                                 Interacts with PD0043|Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|Alberti, et al. (2009) determined Candidate-Prion proteins using an HMM algorithm trained on the sequences of four known yeast prion determinants| Both 'core' and 'extended' prion determinants were predicted by the algorithm|

Comment                                 Interacts with PD0035|Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|Alberti, et al. Comment                                 Interacts with PD0031|Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|

Comment                                 Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|Alberti, et al. Comment                                 Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|Alberti, et al. (2009) determined Candidate-Prion proteins using an HMM algorithm trained on the sequences of four known yeast prion determinants| Both 'core' and 'extended' prion determinants were predicted by the algorithm|

Comment                                 Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|Alberti, et al. (2009) determined Candidate-Prion proteins using an HMM algorithm trained on the sequences of four known yeast prion determinants| Both 'core' and 'extended' prion determinants were predicted by the algorithm|
Variant
Fragment

Epub 2007 Feb 3._17320905 |Harrison PM._Exhaustive assignment of compositional bias reveals universally prevalent biased regions: analysis of functional associations in human and Drosophila. _BMC Bioinformatics. 2006 Oct 10;7:441._17032452 |Harrison PM, Gerstein M. _A method to assess compositional bias in biological sequences and its application to prion-like glutamine/asparagine-rich domains in eukaryotic proteomes. _Genome Biol. 2003;4(6):R40. Epub 2003 May 30. _12801414 |Alberti S, Halfmann R, King O, Kapila A, Lindquist S.  _A systematic survey identifies prions and illuminates sequence features of prionogenic proteins. _Cell. 2009 Apr 3;137(1):146-58. _19345193
Comment                                 Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|Alberti, et al. (2009) determined Candidate-Prion proteins using an HMM algorithm trained on the sequences of four known yeast prion determinants| Both 'core' and 'extended' prion determinants were predicted by the algorithm|

Epub 2007 Feb 3._17320905 |Harrison PM._Exhaustive assignment of compositional bias reveals universally prevalent biased regions: analysis of functional associations in human and Drosophila. _BMC Bioinformatics. 2006 Oct 10;7:441._17032452 |Harrison PM, Gerstein M. _A method to assess compositional bias in biological sequences and its application to prion-like glutamine/asparagine-rich domains in eukaryotic proteomes. _Genome Biol. 2003;4(6):R40. Comment                                 Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|Alberti, et al. (2009) determined Candidate-Prion proteins using an HMM algorithm trained on the sequences of four known yeast prion determinants| Both 'core' and 'extended' prion determinants were predicted by the algorithm|

Epub 2003 May 30. _12801414 |Alberti S, Halfmann R, King O, Kapila A, Lindquist S.  _A systematic survey identifies prions and illuminates sequence features of prionogenic proteins. _Cell. 2009 Apr 3;137(1):146-58. _19345193
Comment                                 Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|Alberti, et al. (2009) determined Candidate-Prion proteins using an HMM algorithm trained on the sequences of four known yeast prion determinants| Both 'core' and 'extended' prion determinants were predicted by the algorithm|

Comment                                 Candidate-Prion proteins in yeast were determined using the compositional bias probability minimization algorithms described in the above references, with a maximum binomial P-value threshold of 1x10^[-10]| These Candidate-Prion proteins are biased purely for N and/or Q residues, or for N and/or Q residues with a subsidiary compositional bias for Y, S or G (with P-value <1x10^[-4]), and do not have contributing biases from charged residues (D, E, R or K) or major hydrophobic residues (V, I, L or M), with P-value <1x10^[-4]| These criteria were derived from analysis of the four first yeast prion determinants that were determined|
